No, Ravi, talent, of course - I think the other way it looks at is the rich movie really garners the most box office hits and the talent.
And how clear is that exist there that brings people - go ahead.
And with the Academy, it's about who lobbies for the awards.
Like, there was a year that I think Eddie Murphy was up for ""Dreamgirls."" He didn't lobby in the way that you do to get the award.
And it was part of why he didn't win the Oscar - people say, right?
OK, but then there was Denzel Washington won twice, you know, Halle Berry won and Viola Davis just won a big award at the Emmys.
And a lot of people are just saying how is it possible - I guess what's the deal?
I mean, is it the same old, same old?
Has anything changed?
Has anything changed?
I think things have changed and are changing.
Obviously, it's not a good sign that we were looking at an all-white nominees here.
But, you know, I just think awards because they're subjective are something that you can only view as a positive if it happens for you and not a negative if it doesn't.

I think specifically when we talk about race - which, by the way, the bigger issue to me is the gender, where we have, you know, 9 percent female-directed films last year - I care more about that, honestly.
But when it comes to race, my question would be who is it that got snubbed?
Because I think it has more to do with us not putting people of color in greater positions of power in these films.
Sam?
And like Viola Davis said, if the roles aren't there, you can't play them.
Exactly.
And, like, how many high-caliber roles are being carved out for people of color to play?

And it's like we can't...

I loved it.
